Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Korea
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Yair Korenblit of Georgia Institute of Technology to conduct a research project, entitled "Nanometer-sized manganese oxide: applications in high energy density batteries," during the summer of 2012 at Ulsan National Institute of Science & Technology (UNIST) in Ulsan Metropolitan City. The host scientist is Dr. Jaephil Cho.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project lies in continued development of low-cost catalysts for metal-sir batteries to compare with such expensive and unsustainable catalysts as platinum-carbon composites. These substitutes are made by adding a pseudo two-dimensional catalyst on a conductive substrate.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the past few years there has been a revitalization of interest in electrochemical energy storage.  In part due to a global political climate change and the recognition of limitations with respect to energy sources, there has been an extensive amount of financial investment into energy storage technologies, both with respect to fundamental studies and commercialization. A plethora of energy storage systems are currently being investigated, including electrochemical devices (e.g. M (lithium, sodium, aluminum)-ion batteries, supercapacitors, fuel cells and metal-air batteries), hydro and thermal storage, and flywheels, that will be necessary to optimize the utilization of renewable energy sources like wind and solar.  Metal-air batteries are an extremely promising candidate to fit the needs of growing demands on portable electronics and energy storage for the grid. This is because of their extremely high energy density. This research effort builds on existing Zinc-air battery research and targets the problems faced by the cathode catalyst, which facilitates the incorporation of air (oxygen) into the system. 

Over the course of the fellowship, our research team was able to synthesize a high surface area carbon never before synthesized with high catalyzing efficiency. The results obtained in this effort were made possible through information exchange from the work of two laboratories focused on the advancement of energy storage technologies and science. The low-cost sucrose solution method was inspired by the work performed at the Georgia Institute of Technology while the melamine foam (providing useful nitrogen chemical groups) was inspired by previous work performed by the researchers at Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology. By combining the work of a third party (Kawamata et. al.) a promising catalyst material was synthesized allowing for future advances in various applications, including metal-air batteries and alkaline fuel cells.


Last Modified: 01/09/2013
Modified by: Yair Korenblit
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: In the past few years there has been a revitalization of interest in electrochemical energy storage. In part due to a global political climate change and the recognition of limitations with respect to energy sources, there has been an extensive amount of financial investment into energy storage technologies, both with respect to fundamental studies and commercialization. A plethora of energy storage systems are currently being investigated, including electrochemical devices (e.g. M (lithium, sodium, aluminum)-ion batteries, supercapacitors, fuel cells and metal-air batteries), hydro and thermal storage, and flywheels, that will be necessary to optimize the utilization of renewable energy sources like wind and solar. Metal-air batteries are an extremely promising candidate to fit the needs of growing demands on portable electronics and energy storage for the grid. This is because of their extremely high energy density. This research effort builds on existing Zinc-air battery research and targets the problems faced by the cathode catalyst, which facilitates the incorporation of air (oxygen) into the system. Over the course of the fellowship, our research team was able to synthesize a high surface area carbon never before synthesized with high catalyzing efficiency. The results obtained in this effort were made possible through information exchange from the work of two laboratories focused on the advancement of energy storage technologies and science. The low-cost sucrose solution method was inspired by the work performed at the Georgia Institute of Technology while the melamine foam (providing useful nitrogen chemical groups) was inspired by previous work performed by the researchers at Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology. By combining the work of a third party (Kawamata et. al.) a promising catalyst material was synthesized allowing for future advances in various applications, including metal-air batteries and alkaline fuel cells.
